Gregor Mendel.passage: Gregor Mendel (March 22, 1822 – January 5, 1884) was an Austrian monk who founded modern genetics. He was the first to describe the principles of inheritance, showing that discrete units of inheritance are passed from parent to offspring. He is also credited with establishing the discipline of genetics as a science. Born to a family of farmers near Brno in Moravia, then part of the Austrian Empire, Mendel was educated by the Benedictine Order. He became a monk at the Abbey of St. Thomas in Brno, where he taught classes in physics and mathematics. In 1856, he published his findings on experiments using garden peas, which had been bred for various traits for centuries, and showed that each character was determined by two factors, one from each parent. He called these factors "elements" or "germ plasm" (today, "gene"). He also showed that these elements could combine in pairs to create the various combinations of traits that were seen in the peas. He published his findings in a paper entitled Experiments on Plant Hybrids, in the Proceedings of the Natural History Society of Brünn, in 1857. Mendel's work went largely unnoticed until the early 20th century, when his ideas were rediscovered and expanded upon by Hugo de Vries and Carl Correns, independently.

Bohr's model of atomic structure was refined by Albert Einstein, who proposed his famous equation E = mc2. Bohr's model was superseded by the model of the atom proposed by Ernest Rutherford in 1911. Bohr's model was, however, the first to correctly explain the hydrogen spectral series, which Rutherford's model could not explain. Bohr was also an influential teacher and mentor to a number of physicists, including Werner Heisenberg and John von Neumann. The book was written as a dialogue between Salviati and Simplicio (an "ass" and a "simpleton"), representing Galileo and the Inquisitor, respectively. Alan Turing.passage: Alan Turing (1912–1954) was an English mathematician, logician, cryptographer and computer scientist. He is best known for his wartime work cracking the German Enigma code, for which he was later prosecuted and convicted of "gross indecency" and sentenced to chemical castration. Turing's work during the war has been called "the single most influential event in the history of the modern computer" and "the single biggest contribution to the Allied victory in World War II". In 1937, Turing was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society, and he delivered its Croonian Lecture in 1941 on "Contributions to the Theory of Final Values". He was appointed a professor at the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology, where he worked on machine learning, and was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh in 1943. Turing's work on the design of a universal computer, and his theoretical description of a stored-program computer, were recognised with the British Royal Society's Adams Prize in 1949, and he was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society in 1952. However, his work on artificial intelligence has been criticised as "premature" and his proposed "Turing test" for machine intelligence has been criticised as being too narrow to be a meaningful measure of "true" intelligence. In 1952, Turing joined the National Physical Laboratory in England, where he designed an early computer.

Richard Dawkins.passage: Richard Dawkins (born 26 June 1941) is an English ethologist, evolutionary biologist and author. He is best known for his controversial and bestselling books The Selfish Gene (1976), The Blind Watchmaker (1986), and The God Delusion (2006), as well as his frequent appearances in the media. Dawkins was born in Oxford, the son of two academic parents. His father, Clive Robert Dawkins, was an anthropologist and his mother, Marianne Margaret Eveleen Barham, was a geneticist. He was educated at Oxford University, where he graduated with first-class honours in natural science and obtained a D. Phil. in genetics. Dawkins is a Fellow of the Linnean Society of London and a Foreign Associate of the US National Academy of Sciences. He was the University of Oxford's Professor for Public Understanding of Science from 1992 to 2008. He was the president of the British Humanist Association from 1995 to 2000. He was the co-founder of the World Science Festival in New York City. Dawkins is a prominent atheist and critic of Intelligent Design and creationism. His works emphasise the importance of science in general, and evolution in particular. He has also written on ethics, feminism, and memetics. Ada Lovelace.passage: Ada Lovelace is an English mathematician and writer. She is best known for her work on Charles Babbage's proposed Analytical Engine, considered by some to be the first computer. She translated and edited the work of Italian mathematician Luigi Menabrea and published the work in 1843, when she was only twenty-one. Ada Lovelace was born in London on 10 December 1815, the only child of Lord Byron's doctor, Dr. Thomas "Tommy" Bowles, and his wife, Annabella Milbanke, Lady Byron. Her mother had been a favourite of Byron's and had been his "Dark Angel". Annabella died in 1815 when Ada was two years old and her father married her mother's sister, Augusta Leigh, in 1816. Ada was named after her mother, but her parents called her "Daisy". Her family was well-educated and cultured. Her mother was a published poet and her father was a well-known doctor, scientist, and poet in his own right. Her paternal grandfather was the poet and cleric William Henry Leigh and her uncle was the poet, painter, and critic William Michael Rossetti. Her maternal great-uncle was the poet and essayist James Henry Leigh Hunt and her great-aunt, the poet and novelist Fanny Brawne.

At the age of 16, he went to work for his brother, a country store owner, as a bookkeeper, and he later became an agent for a telegraph company. He then moved to New York City and worked as an agent for a railroad telegraph company, where he was promoted to chief operator.

Charles Robert Darwin.passage: Charles Robert Darwin (12 February 1809 – 19 April 1882) was an English scientist and author, best known for his contributions to evolutionary biology. He published his theory of evolution by natural selection in his book On The Origin of Species, which has been described as "one of the most influential books in history". Darwin's theory replaced the previously dominant view of "creationism" and "intelligent design", and is the predominant view in modern biology. He also made significant contributions to the fields of botany, zoology, and geology. Darwin's early life and education provided little direction for his future scientific work, although his childhood experiences left a lasting impression on him. He spent much of his time outdoors and was interested in observing and collecting animals, plants, and minerals. His observations and experiments as a child and teenager left an indelible impression on his thought and work. Darwin's early work in geology led him to be selected as the naturalist on the survey ship HMS Beagle, during which time he collected specimens and made observations that laid the foundations of his future work. His five-year circumnavigation of the globe, and the resulting collection of biological and geological samples, convinced him of the power of natural selection to produce new biological species. He later recalled, "It is like looking back 10,000 years and thinking of all the stages of man's progression".

Oxford University.passage: The University of Oxford is a collegiate research university located in Oxford, England. It has a history of English higher education spanning more than 1,100 years, making it the oldest university in the English-speaking world. As of 2019[update], it is the second-oldest university in the world and the oldest in the British Isles. The University of Oxford has the largest academic staff of any university in the world and one of the highest proportions of academic staff to students. It is one of the top two universities in the world by number of academic staff and the fourth-oldest in the world. It was ranked the world's most influential university and the world's fourth-best university by the Academic Ranking of World Universities in its 2020 edition, and the world's best university by "Times Higher Education" in 2021, 2022 and 2025. In the 2023 QS World University Rankings, the University of Oxford was ranked as the world's top university, overtaking Harvard University, and in the 2025 QS World University Rankings, it was ranked second. The University of Oxford has educated two British prime ministers, three British monarchs, and 35 British cabinet ministers. It is the second-most-visited university campus in the world, after Cambridge University.

The General Electric Company was an American multinational conglomerate company headquartered in Fairfield, Connecticut, United States, and a component of the Dow Jones Industrial Average. It was founded in 1892 by Thomas Edison, and was led by chairman and CEO Jeffrey Immelt from 2001 to 2019. GE was ranked as the world’s seventh-largest company by revenue in 2018, the largest U.S.-based non-financial company, and the second-largest U.S. industrial company. The company was founded in 1892 as Edison General Electric Company by inventor Thomas Edison, who served as its chairman until his death in 1931. Edison’s direct descendants held leadership positions within the company until 1956.
